instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2936: What is 820-2936? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1278: What is A1278? A1278 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook or Macbook Pro Unibody from years Late 2008, Mid 2009, Mid 2010, Early 2011, Late 2011, Mid 2012 with EMC 2254, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-2327, 820-2530, 820-2879, 820-2936, 820-3115..

threads.title: SMC is flat against the board... <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B
threads.message:
Hi,

I have an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1278</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> that came in with no power (liquid damage). I noticed while I was inspecting the board that there were signs of rework there already and I really don't think this is a customer diy type of thing but the reason I am posting here is that the SMC is completely flat against the board. Is there some technique that people are using to solder chips like this without reballing? I would have assumed it was some kind of failed attempt at soldering the chip if it wasn't actually powering on booting to the login screen. Here is a picture to show what I'm talking about.

threads.title: SMC is flat against the board... <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B
threads.message: That is normal, that SMC was never touched.

threads.title: SMC is flat against the board... <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B
threads.message: It's harder to see the balls on pre-2012 models.

threads.title: SMC is flat against the board... <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B
threads.message: Thanks for the info, I never expected a bga would sit so low.
